block.p: Re ''No Spitting on the Road to Olympic Glory, Beijing Says'' (news article, April 17):
Re ''No Spitting on the Road to Olympic Glory, Beijing Says'' (news article, April 17):
As a foreigner in China, I have a somewhat different take on the Chinese government's efforts to ''clean up'' the nation's image in preparation for the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

In addition to reported citywide campaigns to curb spitting, cursing, littering, cutting in line, and bad English translations on signs and menus, the Beijing authorities are also tearing down poor neighborhoods, closing down ''undesirable'' businesses, ordering the removal of obvious counterfeit products from store shelves, and enforcing other laws that were previously ignored. Soon the homeless will be relocated.
These practices may be good for the city, but for visitors who would like to see unmitigated China I'd recommend waiting until after the Olympics to visit Beijing's ''Forbidden City.''
Like the infamous busload of SARS patients the authorities hid from the W.H.O. doctors inspecting the Beijing hospitals a few years back, the China-in-hiding will soon be returning.
